awd_abstract_narration:
Dynamical systems play an important role in all the sciences. They occur as models for predator and prey populations, orbits of planets and  weather conditions. Some of the dynamical systems that are easiest to state are obtained by the iteration of a single map, viewed as a function from the real line to the real line, or from the complex plane to the complex plane. More recently researchers in physical sciences have been interested in models given by higher dimensional mappings.  In the complex setting one can make use of complex analytic and geometric tools that are not available in the real one.


The aim of this project is to describe the dynamics of a complex analytic map from a space of several variables to itself in the presence of a fixed point that is parabolic. The local study of holomorphic maps close to a fixed point is well understood (although not complete) in one complex dynamics. In several dimensions however, the situation becomes much more complicated. The PI will also focus on global dynamics in this setting and investigate the possible behaviors of orbits and their relation with multipliers at fixed points. Finally, the PI will explore applications of summability theory in the context of parabolic maps in several dimensions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project deals with studying complex dynamics in the specific setting of parabolic local dynamics; as well as studying classical objects on several complex variables.  
On the complex dynamics front, the PI studied local dynamics of parabolic maps in several complex variables. Local dynamics deals with fixed points for a given holomorphic map; and the action of the iterates of this map on points close to the fixed point. The dynamics are in general dictated by the derivative of the map at the fixed point; however when the derivative does not inform attraction or repelling behavior, the dynamics tend to be pretty involved. The PI has dealt with this specific case, and given several characterization of conditions for which one can guarantee attraction and/or repelling of orbits around the fixed point.
On the several complex variables front, the PI has studied Hardy Spaces and Bergman Spaces. Both objects are classical on study, however several concepts remain open. For instance, one working definition of Hardy Space for singular domains has been proposed by the PI and co-authors. Another classical study is the dimensionality of the Bergman Space of a domain. The PI along with collaborators has given characterizations of this space on different settings.


Last Modified: 10/30/2023
Modified by: Liz R Vivas
